summary: This video essay explores the power of peaceful engagement and dialogue in challenging harmful ideologies, centering on Daryl Davis's unconventional approach to befriending KKK members.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen displaying the text "FEE" in the bottom right corner, transitioning to a bustling street scene at night where people walk and gather. The text "Out of Frame" appears prominently, accompanied by the subtitle "It's a big one." The scene shifts to a daytime protest with individuals holding red flags, and the text "WHAT IS ANTIFA?" appears, followed by "A GROUP THAT CLASHED WITH NAZIS IN CHARLOTTESVILLE." The narrative continues with a man in a helmet and goggles speaking, with the text "and hold opinions and values that we think are just..." displayed. The video then shows a person in a red outfit with a star emblem, with the text "Or even worse..." The scene transitions to a man in a suit being interviewed, with the text "Do we all just escalate the war until somebody gets seriously hurt?" The video then shows a chaotic street scene with debris and a person running, with the text "Obviously, that's not helpful." The video concludes with a group of people in white shirts and masks confronting police officers, with the text "We need to find a way to have a conversation." The video ends with a black screen displaying the text "FEE" and "FEE.org" in the bottom right corner.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a spoken statement from a male speaker expressing concern about widespread disagreement and differing values. His tone is serious, questioning how to deal with such conflicts.  He wonders if continuing the conflict would cause harm, and then he restates his concern. Light music then starts playing. It is slow and relaxing, possibly for background purposes.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene of motorcyclists riding down a street, followed by a transition to a blurred image of a person with text overlaying the image. The text reads, "When people believe in wrongheaded or terrible things, how do we actually persuade them to stop believing the bad ideas, and get them to start believing in good ones instead?" The scene then shifts to a person in a blue shirt sitting in a room with a mural in the background, with the same text overlay. The next scene shows a person in a blue shirt walking in front of a large building, followed by a scene of a person in a blue shirt sitting in a room with a mural in the background, with the text "might have the answer." The video then shows a person in a beige jacket holding a photograph with two children in front of the Washington Monument, with the text "Daryl is the subject of a fantastic documentary called 'Accidental Courtesy,' directed by Matt Ornstein." The final scene shows the title "ACCIDENTAL COURTESY" with an airplane flying in the background. Throughout the video, the text "FEE" is visible in the bottom right corner.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker introduces a problem and suggests a solution involving an individual. The speaker promotes a documentary titled "Accidental Courtesy," sounding informative. Mild background music is present throughout, creating an unobtrusive ambience.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man walking down a narrow alleyway adorned with vibrant murals, dressed in a black shirt and pants. The text overlay reads, "For the past 30 years, Daryl has been traveling the country as a musician engaging in conversations and even forming friendships with members of the Ku Klux Klan." The scene transitions to the same man seated at a grand piano, wearing a yellow shirt and tie, playing music in a room with wooden paneling. The narrative then shifts to a meeting room where three individuals are seated around a table, with the man in a purple shirt engaging in conversation with two others, one of whom is wearing a clerical collar. The text overlay continues, "forming friendships with members of the Ku Klux Klan." The next scene shows the man in a blue shirt shaking hands with another man dressed in a purple robe and wizard hat, identified as "Frank Ancona, Imperial Wizard." The video then moves to an outdoor setting where two men are seated on a porch, one holding a pillow, with the text overlay, "What is it that compels someone to sit down and talk to their worst enemies..." The final scene features the man in a purple shirt standing in front of a screen displaying "DARYL DA," speaking passionately with the text overlay, "DARYL: How can you hate me, when I'm trying to help you?" The video concludes with a close-up of a man's ear and glasses, with the text overlay, "Throughout my life, I've been looking for an answer to that." The video captures Daryl's journey as a musician who engages in meaningful conversations and forms unexpected friendships, highlighting his efforts to bridge divides and seek understanding.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a person who has spent 30 years traveling the country, having conversations and forming friendships with members of the Ku Klux Klan. He poses the question of why someone would choose to talk to their worst enemies instead of fighting. This fades into a different male speaker with a reflective tone, asking, "How can you hate me when you don't even know me?" and states that he has been looking for an answer to that throughout his life.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a scene featuring two individuals, one dressed in a black leather jacket with the word "DARYL" emblazoned on the back, and the other in a white robe adorned with a red cross emblem, standing before a backdrop of flames. The text at the bottom of the screen reads, "So I began seeking out members of the Ku Klux Klan." The scene transitions to a close-up of a burning cross with the words "Can We Talk?" displayed above it, maintaining the same subtitle. The narrative then shifts to a man in a purple shirt and tie, speaking in front of a wooden barrel and a screen, with the subtitle, "It's a great question." The video continues with the same man, now with the subtitle, "And to find out, Daryl went on a mission to seek out and engage with high-ranking members of the KKK." The scene then cuts to a view from inside a car, showing a man in the driver's seat, with the same subtitle displayed. The video concludes with a photograph of two men, one in a green robe with various patches and the other in a pink shirt holding a red cross emblem, standing in front of a brick wall with a banner that reads, "LET GOD." The subtitle remains consistent throughout, emphasizing the mission to engage with high-ranking members of the Ku Klux Klan.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker announcing his intent to "begin seeking out members of the Ku Klux Klan", speaking with an inquisitive tone. This transitions into a male speaker with a thoughtful and analytical tone, reflecting upon this decision. He notes that finding out more led Darryl "on a mission to seek out and engage with high ranking members of the KKK".

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a scene of two men sitting at a table in a restaurant, engaged in conversation. The man on the left is wearing a beige shirt, while the man on the right is dressed in a white shirt. The restaurant's walls are adorned with framed pictures and certificates. The scene transitions to a television screen displaying a news segment with the headline "FRIEND OF THE KLAN" and the name "PHILA ZAHN" visible. The text on the screen reads "He's invited them into his home," indicating a discussion about the man's interactions with the Klan. The video then shows a newspaper article titled "An improbable friendship," featuring a photo of two men, one in a white robe and the other in a suit, with the caption "Black musician, KKK leader pals despite differences." The article discusses the unlikely friendship between a black musician and a KKK leader. The video continues with another newspaper article titled "Understanding the Klan," with the headline "Black man makes it his mission to change leaders' hearts." The article is written by John Thompson and discusses the efforts of a black man to change the hearts of Klan leaders. The video then shows a man in a white robe holding a flaming torch, with the text "DARYL: Tom Robb would tell you that he is not my friend." The scene shifts to a man in a suit sitting in front of an American flag, with the text "He'll make that very clear to you." The video concludes with a man in a teal shirt sitting in a room with a desk and a mirror with lights, with the text "I am Tom Robb's friend." The video explores the complex and controversial relationships between individuals and the Klan, highlighting the efforts of some to bridge the gap between different groups.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker describes how he has invited people into his home, had conversations with them, and considers some of them friends, despite how unlikely it seems. Another male speaker interjects, asserting that Tom Robb would say he is not his friend, and that he, the speaker, is Tom Robb's friend. He expresses hope that Tom Robb will eventually come around.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a view of a cloudy sky and green trees, accompanied by the text "Daryl might say that he's not really even doing anything special." The scene transitions to a man in a light purple shirt sitting in a room with wooden walls, speaking about treating people with respect and kindness. The text "besides treating people with respect and kindness" appears on the screen. The man is then shown sitting in a different room with a piano and framed pictures in the background, continuing his conversation. The scene shifts to another man in a blue shirt and beige vest, who responds with "I guess that's true." The video then moves to a protest scene with a large crowd holding a banner that reads "AGAINST WHITE PRIVILEGE," with the text "It's still something almost no one else has the courage to do, even when the risks are considerably lower" displayed. The final frames show a group of people, including a woman in a floral shirt and a man in a black t-shirt, participating in the protest, with the same text overlay. The video captures a mix of personal reflection and public activism, highlighting themes of respect, kindness, and the courage to challenge societal norms.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker suggesting that Darryl might dismiss his actions as simply treating people with respect and kindness. He concedes that this is true, before adding that it's a rare quality even when risks are low.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a man in a yellow shirt shaking hands with another person in a black suit, set against a backdrop of framed pictures and a paper towel dispenser. The scene transitions to a black-and-white image of a man in a checkered shirt, with a book titled "The Emotional Brain" by Daryl R. Damasio displayed beside him. The narrative then shifts to a close-up of a brain scan, highlighting the amygdala, with text explaining its role in hijacking rational minds. The video continues with a crowd scene, where people are seen in a heated confrontation, accompanied by text discussing the fight or flight response. A scientific article titled "Biased Assimilation and Attitude Polarization" is shown, followed by a scene of a protest with individuals wearing red hats and black shirts, emphasizing the impact of evidence on people's beliefs. The video concludes with a discussion between two men in a formal setting, discussing persuasive communication techniques, with the Kansas state flag visible in the background. Throughout the video, the FEE logo is consistently present in the bottom right corner.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker defending a particular approach, stating that it "has a lot of empirical support" from neuroscientists and psychologists who study persuasion. He uses a calm and explanatory tone, citing psychological studies that indicate people's emotions can hijack their rational minds and cause them to react defensively when their core beliefs are challenged. He continues, explaining that, presenting conflicting arguments may backfire. He further states "We also know a lot about how to talk to people in ways that are actually persuasive."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a suit and tie, sitting in front of a white background with square cutouts, discussing Robert Cialdini's book "Influence" and its principles of persuasion. The scene transitions to a close-up of the book's cover, highlighting its title and the subtitle "The Psychology of Persuasion." A hand then writes on a whiteboard, listing the "6 Shortcuts" of persuasion: Reciprocity, Scarcity, Authority, Consistency, Liking, and Consensus. The focus shifts to the concept of "Reciprocity," illustrated by a hand drawing a thumbs-up and a signpost labeled "Shortcut." The narrative continues with a man in a white robe and hat, identified as Roger Kelly, the Imperial Wizard of the Invisible Empire, speaking into a microphone. The scene then moves to a dimly lit bar where a group of people are seated around a table, engaging in conversation and enjoying drinks. The text on the screen emphasizes the principle of reciprocity, stating that people feel obliged to treat you the way you treat them. The video concludes with a scene of a man in a black cap and jacket interacting with a crowd, with the text on the screen suggesting that treating others with contempt will result in a negative response. The overall atmosphere of the video is educational, with a focus on explaining psychological principles through visual aids and real-life examples.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with soft, contemplative background music that establishes a thoughtful atmosphere. A male voice begins speaking in a calm, informative tone, discussing Robert Cialdini's principles of persuasion, specifically focusing on reciprocity, which he explains is "based on the idea that people feel obliged to treat you the way you treat them". The music continues softly under his narration. He adds that kindness and humility typically elicit similar responses, while contempt can lead to a negative outcome. He ends with the rhetorical question, "Well, what do you think?".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a black shirt and glasses, smiling and engaging with a crowd, with the text "What do you think?" displayed at the bottom. The scene transitions to a man in a purple shirt speaking in an indoor setting, with a guitar and decorative vase in the background. The text reads, "any racist agenda or supremacist agenda," followed by "I do support their right and their freedom of speech," and "And their right to express their views." The narrative continues with the same man in the purple shirt, emphasizing the importance of freedom of speech and expression, with the text "And in doing so, guess what, they reciprocate it." The scene shifts to two men in white chef's uniforms conversing, with the text "Another principle Cialdini describes is the idea of 'liking'." The video then shows a man holding a guitar in front of a Confederate flag, with the text "It's almost too obvious, but it turns out that if someone likes you personally." The final scene features two men walking towards the Lincoln Memorial, with the text "It's easier to convince them that your way of thinking is worth considering." The video explores themes of freedom of speech, personal likability, and persuasion, using various settings and individuals to convey its message.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip opens with a male speaker firmly asserting that he doesn't support racist agendas or supremacy, but advocates for freedom of speech and expression of views, noting that doing so is reciprocated. This transitions into a discussion by a second male speaker, with an intellectual and thoughtful tone, on the principle of "liking." He emphasizes that if someone likes you and believes you like them, it's easier to convince them to consider your way of thinking.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a panel discussion featuring three individuals seated on stage, engaged in a conversation about the importance of finding common ground and building relationships. The setting is a formal event, with a backdrop displaying the logo of the Foundation for Economic Education (FEE) and the year 1968. The panelists, dressed in business attire, discuss the ease of convincing others to consider one's way of thinking and the value of listening to others. The scene transitions to a close-up of a person playing a piano, emphasizing the importance of shared interests in building connections. The narrative then shifts to a man in a blue shirt presenting a certificate to another man in a purple robe, symbolizing the idea of becoming part of someone's tribe. The video continues with a discussion on the surprising commonalities between seemingly disparate individuals, illustrated by a scene featuring a man in a suit and a KKK member, highlighting the potential for unexpected connections. The focus then moves to a man in a purple shirt and tie, who elaborates on the concept of finding common ground and building relationships. The video concludes with a scene of a man in a blue shirt placing a purple hat with a gold star and cross on another man's head, symbolizing the diminishing importance of superficial differences like skin color as one builds deeper connections. Throughout the video, the FEE logo is visible, reinforcing the theme of economic education and the importance of understanding human relationships.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a calm male voice describing how listening and finding common ground is a shortcut to friendship, and uses an example of Darryl Davis who might have nothing in common with KKK members. This transitions into another male speaker with a slightly raspy voice who says that spending just "five minutes" with your "arch enemy" will reveal commonalities, and that "skin color" will matter "less and less" as the shared ground expands. The clip concludes with the initial male voice noting that these relationships have had "an interesting side effect".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene showing a group of people in a room, with one person wearing a white robe and hood, reminiscent of a Ku Klux Klan outfit, while another person in a military uniform stands nearby. The text on the screen reads, "In the last couple decades," indicating a historical context. The scene transitions to a man in a purple shirt folding a white robe, with the text stating, "over 200 of America's most ardent white supremacists have hung up their robes and hoods for good." This suggests a significant shift in attitudes or actions among a group of individuals. The video then shows a newspaper article with the headline "Klan leader quits, may run for governor," dated July 10, 1999, from Annapolis, MD, highlighting a notable event related to the topic. The narrative continues with a man in a purple shirt standing in a room with a white robe hanging on a rack, accompanied by the text, "Many of those robes now hang in Daryl's closet." This implies a personal connection to the historical context. The video then shows a man in a purple shirt holding a white robe with a red cross emblem, with the text, "And in a lot of cases, these individual conversions have much bigger consequences." This suggests that personal changes can have broader impacts. The scene shifts to a person wearing a white robe with a red cross emblem, standing outdoors, with the text, "and may end multi-generational cycles of bigotry." This indicates the potential for significant social change. The video concludes with a woman speaking into a microphone, with the text, "and may end multi-generational cycles of bigotry," reinforcing the message of transformation and the potential for ending long-standing prejudices.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker discussing white supremacists and their changes of heart, mentioning "hung up their robes and hoods" and potentially breaking cycles of "bigotry." He speaks in a conversational tone. There are no other distinguishable voices or musical elements present.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a television interview with a man in a suit holding a microphone, interviewing a group of people, including two young girls named Erica and Erin Puig. The setting appears to be a studio with a colorful background. The interviewer, Geraldo, asks the girls about their parents' involvement in certain organizations, and Erin responds that she is proud of her parents' race and identity. The scene then shifts to a man in a suit, presumably the father, who is asked if he will join the group. The video then shows a man with long hair and a beard, wearing a black t-shirt and suspenders, being interviewed by the same man in a suit. The interviewer mentions that the father was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison and humorously suggests calling the mother Tina. The video captures a mix of serious and light-hearted moments, with the interviewees and interviewer displaying various expressions and gestures. The atmosphere is casual, with the interview taking place in a studio setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a young girl identifying herself as Aaron and stating her age. She speaks in a neutral tone when discussing her parents belonging to organizations, and when asked about it says she thinks it is "fine". She expresses her belief that they are "allowed to like their race" and that she will also be a member of their group. This is followed by a male speaker who announces that both daughters are now in the Klan and that their father was sentenced to ten years in federal prison. The speaker says that they plan to call the mother, named Tina. The audio clip ends abruptly.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a map highlighting Chicago and Marion, IL, accompanied by a caption about a journey to a federal penitentiary. It transitions to an exterior view of a prison with high fences and barbed wire, emphasizing the security measures. The narrative then shifts to a television screen showing a woman speaking at a podium, with the text "And nobody in the Klan had ever done that for them before." The woman, identified as Tina, continues speaking, expressing gratitude for her daughters' transformation, with the text "Well, my little girls came a long way. You know, no thanks to her father and I." The video captures a significant moment of change and redemption, set against the backdrop of a prison and a public address, highlighting themes of personal growth and societal impact.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker detailing a story of a man affiliated with the KKK who drove people out to see their father in prison, something that no one else had done for them before. Following this, a female speaker chimes in, reflecting on how her child came a long way despite her and the father's efforts, to seemingly sabotage their kids. There are no apparent background sounds or music in the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a family sitting on a couch, with the woman in the center wearing a light blue shirt and the man on the left in a dark shirt with a pink tie. The man on the right is wearing a light blue shirt with the word "Abercrombie" printed on it. The family appears to be in a living room with a white curtain in the background. The text on the screen reads, "ERIN: Me and my husband Harley would like to the City of Rockville, MD, as you celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King." The scene then transitions to a man in a yellow shirt and black tie speaking, with the text, "We live in a time when a lot of people are saying that the only answer to hate and awful ideas is to meet them with even more hate, more anger, outrage, and even..." The video then shows a group of people wearing black hoodies and masks with the text "WHAT IS ANTIFA? INSIDE THE GROUP THAT CLASHED WITH NAZIS IN CHARLOTTESVILLE" on the screen. The final scene depicts a chaotic street scene with people running and a police car, with the text, "is to meet them with even more hate, more anger, outrage, and even..." The video appears to be discussing the topic of Antifa and their actions in response to hate and hate groups.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a woman expressing well wishes, mentioning a celebration of Dr. Martin Luther King and stating that neither she nor her family are currently affiliated with the Ku Klux Klan. This speech transitions to a man speaking about the prevailing attitude of responding to hate with more hate, anger, outrage, and even violence, adopting a concerned tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a news broadcast featuring a tweet from WTVR CBS 6 Richmond about a person with a bandaged head who had to get stitches, alongside a CNN news ticker discussing Dan Harmon, creator of Rick & Morty, Community, and a comic book. The scene transitions to a stage where a man in a blue shirt speaks into a microphone, with another man in a yellow shirt seated at a table, and a third man in a blue suit at a podium. The text overlay reads, "Recently, Dan Harmon, creator of Rick & Morty, Community, and one of my favorite comic books ever even said the." The video then shifts to an animated sequence from the show "Rick and Morty," featuring a character in a spacesuit and a menacing creature with red eyes and a UFO. The title "Scud: The Disposable Assassin" appears, followed by a return to the stage where the man in the blue shirt continues speaking, with the text overlay stating, "that the time for talking was 'over'." The man in the blue shirt gestures emphatically, while the man in the yellow shirt listens attentively. The video concludes with the man in the blue shirt delivering a quote, "We have sat, we have talked, we have argued, we have pondered... The discourse is over," emphasizing his point with hand gestures. The background remains dark, focusing attention on the speakers and the text overlay.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one person, a man, speaking with a contemplative tone. He references Dan Harmon and indicates disagreement with the notion that "the time for talking was over." This is followed by a separate audio segment featuring a male voice declaring, "We have sat, we have talked, we have argued, we have pondered; the discourse is over" in a resolute tone. The clip then concludes with the first male speaker responding with "But I disagree."

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen displaying the text "I disagree." in yellow, followed by the FEE logo in the bottom right corner. The scene transitions to a chaotic street protest where a large crowd is seen throwing objects at a building, with the text "Most of human history is filled with people allowing their arguments to turn into bloody, horrific warfare." displayed at the bottom. The next scene shows a white armored vehicle with the letters "GNB" on it amidst the crowd, with the text "It's only the commitment to dealing with our adversaries peacefully." The video then shifts to an aerial view of a military aircraft with a mounted machine gun, accompanied by the same text. Following this, a group of people, including clergy members, are shown kneeling and praying on a street, with the text "It's only the commitment to dealing with our adversaries peacefully." The scene then transitions to a park bench with a sign that reads "The Answer to Hate Speech is More Speech," with the text "WHAT IS ANTIFA? INSIDE THE GROUP THAT CLASHED WITH NAZIS IN CHARLOTTESVILLE" displayed at the bottom. The video then shows a man in a red sweater and blue suit sitting on a couch, speaking to another man in a gray suit, with the text "that has allowed us to become more civilized." The final scene features a man in a white shirt and black cap standing in front of a television screen displaying a news broadcast, with the text "DARYL: I did not respect what he had to say." The video concludes with the FEE logo on a black screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker, in a thoughtful tone, discussing how humanity's ability to engage in peaceful dialogue and free speech has led to increased civilization, transitioning into a second, confident-sounding male speaker stating he respected the first person's right to speak despite not respecting the content. The clip concludes with a non-distinct ambient noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a man in a purple shirt knocking on a door, accompanied by a news ticker discussing a year-long deal and a toxicology report. The scene transitions to an interview in a kitchen, where the same man, identified as Bob White, a former Klansman, converses with another man in a white sweatshirt. The discussion revolves around the effectiveness of techniques in convincing white supremacists. The setting shifts to a diner, where an elderly woman in a pink jacket and a man in a black jacket engage in a conversation, with the text overlay emphasizing the importance of genuine conversations with people outside one's bubble. The video then moves to a protest scene, featuring a woman in a black shirt and a man in a black t-shirt with a red logo, holding a sign that reads "DC ANTIFA." The text overlay suggests that engaging in such conversations can lead to personal growth. The scene transitions to a crowded event, where a man in a purple shirt and a woman with curly blonde hair are seated, with the text overlay encouraging viewers to change for the better. The video then shows a protest with a man in a black tank top and a red bandana, holding a sign that reads "ANTI-RACIST," with the text overlay advising against shouting down wrong ideas. The final scene features a split-screen image of a man in a black leather jacket and a hooded figure with a red cross, with the text overlay discussing the strength of the Ku Klux Klan and the courage required to challenge it. The video concludes with a man in a purple shirt speaking on a news program, with the text overlay emphasizing the importance of confronting evil ideas.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing techniques for convincing people, contrasting "diehard white supremacists" with "friends, neighbors, and co-workers." His tone is persuasive, suggesting that genuine conversations can lead to personal growth. This transitions into a section where he discusses dealing with "wrong or evil ideas" by making "a friend out of an enemy," which is delivered in a reflective tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with two men standing in a wooded area, one dressed in a white robe with a tall white hat and a sash adorned with various badges, while the other wears a red sweater. They appear to be engaged in a conversation, with the man in the red sweater gesturing with his hands. The scene then transitions to a black and white graphic with the text "out of FRAME" and "FEE presents," followed by a description of the content as "video essays on the intersection of art, culture, and ideas written & edited by sean w. malone." The video continues with a black and white graphic featuring the text "FEE" and "FEE.org," along with social media icons and the handle "@feeeonline." The final frames show a white background with the text "FEE" and "FEE.org" in black, followed by a black and white graphic with the text "FEE" and "FEE.org" in black, and a white background with the text "FEE" and "FEE.org" in black. The video concludes with a black and white graphic featuring the text "FEE" and "FEE.org" in black, along with social media icons and the handle "@feeeonline."
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a friendly, conversational introduction to a show called "Out of Frame," followed by a call to action for viewer feedback and subscription.  This is followed by suggesting the viewers to check out "@fee online" on social media. The clip has one male speaker.
